on Cancer (IARC), which is a part of the WHO, has now advised that people should avoid this food as far as possible. It was probably the team of about 20 scientists who thought of classifying red meat as “probably” carcinogenic which made the big headlines. After several cuts in red meat consumption, the team still stands by this assessment, as risk doubles with each 50 grams a day (about two slices of bread). Similarly, for processed meat the risk doubles for every 50-gram portion a day (the equivalent to about three slices of bacon or two rashers of ham). The panel considered whether cooking techniques and additives in meat differed from country to country and/or affected the risk analysis. In addition, it analyzed additional survey data, including from countries such as the United Kingdom and Germany, where bacon and ham are commonly eaten.

of mid-green or bronze-green, tubular flowers which are followed by dark green calyces. From early March until May the tall stems bear racemes of the flowers which begin in brilliant light blue and fade to a slightly darker blue, then soft lilac, then finally silver. In mid-May the flower colour intensifies. Every stem terminates in a series of star-shaped flower heads, the orange tubes turning to a clean lemon colour in late summer.
Clusters of pink, lavender and white fleshy fruits form as the flowers begin. After flowering the plant produces seed on the branches lending a golden haze above as bloom goes into seed. This changes to a glistening green and brown after rain. After flowering the plant dies back in summer while retaining foliage to protect seeds. Oxford, the traditional city of the Inns of Court. My great love of history, particularly ancient Rome, nearly kept me from ever going over there. It was no small pleasure for an Italian from a Roman Catholic background to walk past a local church or cemetery, as would pass through a temple of the goddess Fortuna or a line forming before the marble bust of Emperor Augustus. Somehow the days that we walked past these centuries-old sites had better retention than the talk sessions that took place before we rounded the corner out of earshot and into the cafeteria area where a table was set up for a free meal.
Cramming an intense Western Civ course into this real-life experience proved a challenge, perhaps in part accounting for the eventual skin condition known as a lupus flare. It did, however, provide ample opportunity to observe up close the workings of the legal system of an advanced civilization

Consider the way fine art talks to you: it transcends technique, the craft to which an artist commits years to master. an American foursquare. It was Eastern European in look, as many foursquares are. It was an older hand-built home, long-gone from the neighborhood. First, determine who you are writing to at the company. Generally, you will write the name of the addressee first—100 Main Street, John Smith, Sales Division, New York, NY, for example. This is best practice for addressing a business letter, and it shows respect to the recipient.
If the name of the addressee is unknown, it is important to write down their title or department instead. Many companies have departments within departments, so you might need to write down John Smith’s division as Sales Division, Vice President of Sales Division, or HR.
For international correspondence, the exact address of the recipient may be more important. You will also wish to know the postcode or zip code where the letter should be delivered. This information allows the postman to attempt delivery even if the addressee is out of the office at the time.

He died Aug. 24 from complications of a strained aorta, which doctors said had been eating away at his body for many years, essentially lining the artery with calcium.
At one point, Melo suffered another aortic attack and faced having one of his ankles amputated. Doctors were able to successfully clean the strain out and operate on him once again. Despite two additional surgeries to remove the calcium buildup again, Melo never recovered and had to undergo constant dialysis treatments.
At his death at age 66, Melo was rated one of the top city officials in Siskiyou County in overall effectiveness.

The biggest difference is money. Most other states use fewer tests than Utah does.

T. S. Eliot’s famous poem, The Waste Land, as part of an OU investigative journalism course conceived and run by Andrew Mackie. In The Waste Land as an iPad App, MAC explores the poem and gives each section a visual spin, taking more liberty with it than any other website, despite less than 1% of the poem’s value being altered as audio. This sort of tinkering with ebooks (with added audio?) is exciting, but The Waste Land app turned out unsatisfying because MacMaster chose to stop editing T. S. Eliot’s work after his death. It’s a topic I’ve covered before: using rare editions to diacritize biblical commentaries and healing the forgotten texts of T. S. Eliot’s life and work. So what we really want is every text available as a novel interpretation that we might make use of.

My thesis is this: it is not hard to collect data; it is hard to acquire the right amount of data. But analyzing large sets of data, it is not nearly as hard as it is made out to be. The principal reasons are a purely human one, namely that social phenomena are complex and very often not mutually consistent: The real problem then is not data volume, but data quality and consistency. This human “problem” has been one central theme of my own research.
In computer science, we try to answer questions using complete, well-defined languages. Formulating complex questions to a computer sounds simple, but we have to study carefully about what kind of interpretations we allow before expect to discover new phenomena. In human sciences, our ideas should mature in a broader, more unpredictable environment. This twin concept is the

ia by suspending antibiotics within biofilm. Biofilms are naturally occurring ecosystems found on almost all surfaces or objects in nature that almost all microorganisms inhabit. In biofilms, free floating bacteria bind together and form communities, protecting them from antimicrobial agents while allowing host cells to survive. Their microenvironments might encourage the community’s growth. Capsaicin, the compound that makes hot chili peppers hot and cayenne pepper red, is the type of compound frequently occurring in biofilms, including those of Streptococcus species. This limitation suggested to use cayenne pepper as bacterial food to immortalize their cells and thus build the foundations of an antimicrobial food garment.

An eagerly awaited report from the World Health Organization (WHO) states that processed meats such as bacon and sausages cause cancer, and red meat likely does so too.
The France-based International Agency for Research on Cancer (IARC), which is a part of the WHO, has now advised that people should avoid this food as far as possible. It was probably the team of about 20 scientists who thought of classifying red meat as “probably” carcinogenic which made the big headlines. After several cuts in red meat consumption, the team still stands by this assessment, as risk doubles with each 50 grams a day (about two slices of bread). Similarly, for processed meat the risk doubles for every 50-gram portion a day (the equivalent to about three slices of bacon or two rashers of ham). The panel considered whether cooking techniques and additives in meat differed from country to country and/or affected the risk analysis. In addition, it analyzed additional survey data, including from countries such as the United Kingdom and Germany, where bacon and ham are commonly eaten.

WASHINGTON (AP) — Democratic lawmakers must soon decide whether President Barack Obama is leading them toward statesmanlike courage or political folly.
Obama used his first State of the Union speech Wednesday night to try to strike perennial, paradoxical balance. In entreating Republicans to accept his spending and energy proposals, Obama pressed the march toward the right center he described as "the next great American movement." And in laying out expansive education, health care and tax reform plans, Obama hammered the "lessons of history" — the essential prosperity of the post-World War II economy, the dangers of selfishness and the nation's historic commitment to its citizens.
''How can we rebuild?'' Obama asked, asking the country to "all do our part . . . to save our country from the specter of an epic fiscal collapse.''

Sponsored by Sen. Tom Carper (D-Del.), the Diesel Emissions Reduction Act (DERA) of 2019 would reauthorize the program at the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) under which public and private fleets can get rebates of up to 25% of the cost to replace or repower older, more polluting diesel vehicles with new (or newer) ones. DERA is worth supporting because it helps EPA and other stakeholders get rid of the most-polluting Class 8 tractor trailers coast-to-coast. It’s one of the few programs that helps make older class 8 tractor trailers a thing of the past. This is no small matter when you consider that trucks are responsible emit more Greenhouse Gases than all but a handful of Western states and that aging trucks increase air pollution ten-fold. Reauthorization of course would include the most recent NOx standards set by the Obama administration designed to strengthen emission standards in some states and increase maintenance of national standards for diesel emissions. You cannot overestimate the mood of paranoia, hilarity and madness that pervades Westminster. Normal looking MPs seem to have messages branded on their foreheads: "tennis court repairs, paving a cellar". The reserve and civility of the Commons is gone and dissension reigns. Returning parties have strained into their seats, peopled and packed. Even the Whips seem to have lost control of themselves. How can we account for such behaviour, they are asked. MPs refuse to answer, cowed. A debate in the Lords is over and a lady beside me rocks and laughs. It is for Doreen, the flattener of chalk lines on the netball court. It is all going on . . ."

Why are American women dying in childbirth?
Maternal mortality rates are falling in every industrialised nation - except for the United States.
The United States is not the first place that springs to mind when considering women dying in childbirth; Ireland would have been an inconceivable choice not so long ago. Traditionally, less developed nations have long been associated with such tragedies due to unavailable resources and can only be drearily viewed in statistics.
Yet, the United States is currently the world's fifth highest hub for such occurrences - and the highest in the Western Hemisphere, for which there are approximately 30 percent more deaths per 100,00 women’s births than there are in Australia and Canada combined, despite the vastness of the United States in comparison to Europe, as would have to be acknowledged.

WHEN predicting which planets beyond Earth could support life, astronomers usually follow the water. Exoplanets with rocky surfaces are declared habitable if they orbit far enough from their star to potentially host oceans.
But as astronomers celebrated the detection of a candidate Earth cousin this June, the alien world was remarkably arid. Shawana was at least 60% covered in temperate desert or seasonal snow with no oceanic bodies readily visible.
Hence, the determination that its discovery was worth telling the world came as a surprise to planetary scientists, put generally out of the habit of finding a hidden oasis when looking for seas. "It was unusual to get hit with such an obvious dry island," says Dominika Borkowska at the International Space Science Institute and Copenhagen University, Denmark. "I am very sceptical of whether we can think of that world as a habitable planet any more than inclinations towards a sense of Earth."

Most gardeners think of diascias as low-growing bedding plants suited to a summer container or the front of a sunny border.
However Diascia personata breaks the mould and produces stiff stems of mid-green or bronze-green, tubular flowers which are followed by dark green calyces. From early March until May the tall stems bear racemes of the flowers which begin in brilliant light blue and fade to a slightly darker blue, then soft lilac, then finally silver. In mid-May the flower colour intensifies. Every stem terminates in a series of star-shaped flower heads, the orange tubes turning to a clean lemon colour in late summer.
Clusters of pink, lavender and white fleshy fruits form as the flowers begin. After flowering the plant produces seed on the branches lending a golden haze above as bloom goes into seed. This changes to a glistening green and brown after rain. After flowering the plant dies back in summer while retaining foliage to protect seeds. In the summer of 1993, I had one of those experiences that stay with me for the rest of my life.
I spent 10 weeks in Europe, beginning with a six-week law-school summer session at Oxford, the traditional city of the Inns of Court. My great love of history, particularly ancient Rome, nearly kept me from ever going over there. It was no small pleasure for an Italian from a Roman Catholic background to walk past a local church or cemetery, as would pass through a temple of the goddess Fortuna or a line forming before the marble bust of Emperor Augustus. Somehow the days that we walked past these centuries-old sites had better retention than the talk sessions that took place before we rounded the corner out of earshot and into the cafeteria area where a table was set up for a free meal.
Cramming an intense Western Civ course into this real-life experience proved a challenge, perhaps in part accounting for the eventual skin condition known as a lupus flare. It did, however, provide ample opportunity to observe up close the workings of the legal system of an advanced civilization

The trial of Washington Post correspondent Jason Rezaian, on vague charges including espionage, began in Iran on Tuesday.
On Tuesday, the trial of Washington Post reporter Jason Rezaian, who has been imprisoned since July, started. He was charged with vague offenses that suggest his crime was that he was passing a report back home that didn't fit into the theocratic regime's own preferred version of reality.
Rezaian, an Iran-born American national who appears in two bone-colored photographs that were published by the International New York Times, has been denied visits from anyone, including his wife, Yeganeh Salehi, who works for the Post.
It is a clear violation of the 1961 Vienna Convention that Iran sign, that guaranteed consular access for all nationals of another country who were being detained or being held against their will. Now that his trial has started, the publication by the International New York Times shows how serious this is.

Jalapenos are used in many spicy dishes and used fresh, dried eaten pickled.
Jalapeno peppers are among the warm-season hot peppers of the Solanaceae family. Hot peppers grow well in soils that are low in nitrogen and voluminous in organic matter. Peppers will thrive with less water. Peppers generally do not require fertilizer, as soil additives are sold over the counter to help build organic matter in the garden.
Jalapeno peppers make a nice container plant all summer if fed lightly. It can grow outside or a tree in a large pot. "Jalimos," as they are affectionately known in Santiago, Chile, are very low-calorie (these being human beings). They will grow in hot weather and produce riotous amounts of hot peppers.
Jalapeno peppers grow well in full sun and moderate temperatures.Water regularly with good quality water (don't put garden water in your jalapeno plants until they are ripe and have lost all possibility of developing disease).

As a Special Forces intelligence analyst, Snearston knew the most important thing to look for chez Osama bin Laden to confirm a sighting wasn't his robe, his purple patch, or even a distinctive mole—it was his twenty-second cheek. Unfortunately, the euphoria ignored a glaring (and largely known) weakness of so-called market-based solutions – they don’t actually reduce CO2 emissions. They merely defer the tough CO2 reductions. Students have long applied to colleges and universities with applications that are heavy on test scores and grades. While that's not necessarily wrong, the founders of ZeeMee believe it doesn't tell the whole story. In particular, the experiences that young people regularly share with this emerging social networking site tell a very trustworthy story about someone's achievement — including character traits, leadership skills, creativity, circumstances that people face and the solutions they adopt — and motivations that they use to somehow strive and succeed. Their hope is that social networking for this purpose becomes yet another avenue for telling the entire student's story in ways that conventional application materials might not.
For over 40 years, the test-score focused acumen of selection committees at nearly every college and university have driven out subjective decision making in determining students' worthiness of acceptance. Part of the solution has always been for applicants to write essays that tell their story, much earlier in the selection process. Granite Geek: When is a drought not a drought?
Right now in Concord, we are living in a meteorological puzzle: The National Weather Service says this is the wettest August since records began being kept here in Concord in the 1930s. And right now meteorologists are telling us this is the driest July we’ve had since 1952. Thus the current drought or wet island smack right in the middle of that contradiction. In the midst of the confusion, it is clear that not enough water has been dripping from my many beer can collection.
How is this possible? The Emergency Management folks pronounced the state in a drought emergency, the statewide rainfall is below average and the soil moisture is starting to be an issue for people’s gardens and lawns. How can this be true? The cause is a rainfall profile shifted along the western edge of the state where nearly all the heavy rains have fallen. Seven years ago the Internal Revenue Service (IRS) audited one out of every 90 individual income tax returns. Last year it was one out of every 119. This year it is expected to be just one out of every 154.
For many taxpayers this means there are too many people in line before them so the IRS does not audit all returns. Unfortunately, the time, money and privacy of taxpayers must be wasted by sending returns to a computer program that will only respond to gimmick returns in ways that every taxpayer knows will trip the IRS predictive software.
How much would it cost the IRS to go back to a time when one out of 90 returns was audited? Under $1,200 per year for every taxpayer.
What could the IRC do with that money? Figure each taxpayer owes $15,000 in taxes, the IRS would need to audit 1566 persons every year just to meet its target.
Personal financial review software does all the work for each taxpayer, providing easy to understand answers

I ran away from home at the age of 40. It was a home I had wanted for a long time, walked past when I lived a few blocks away. I finally got my wish and was able to buy it. It was an American foursquare. It was Eastern European in look, as many foursquares are. It was an older hand-built home, long-gone from the neighborhood. It was a shoddily sided house, as this was before windows and siding standards started, it was simply done when people needed a place. It was part painted, part wood. It had rickety plastic shutters in springtime, the window frames did not. It had a basement that went back to the basement. It had a fieldstone wall, that simply held up the foundation. It was fun and quirky.

Proclus of Athens (*412–485 C.E.) was the most authoritative philosopher of late antiquity and played a crucial role in the transmission of Platonic philosophy from antiquity to the Middle Ages. This was not only true for its philosophical contents, but also for its special presentation and later reception. Although Proclus’ presentation differs significantly with regard to content and format from early Platonic texts, it is nevertheless archaic in character. Many scholars even believe that its Platonic tradition derives from Proclus himself. In any case, however, it is very different from Christian texts of the period of patristic exegesis. Its presentation and conceptual content do not correspond to a normative text. This indicates the internal heterogeneity of the Platonic writing of the time of the Neoplatonist Proclos. Together with Proclus this study examines the work of the Neoplatonist Iamblichus of Chalcis (ca. 240–ca. 325 C.E.), with whom Proclus shared an intensive activity until Iamblichus’ death. Centralizing the procurement process, diversifying supplier portfolios and assessing the capabilities of each manufacturing partner will allow enterprises to mitigate the impact of or eliminate product recalls.
In 1986, one percent of the annual global tire market was lost as a result of recalls, according to Allied Market Research. This year, the figure is closer to 10%. The danger that product recalls can hold such devastating effects on a company's future has increased to a terrifying degree within the past decade. Enterprises must get serious about the supplier selection process, prioritize safety in each step and eliminate the bottlenecks that create costly, time-consuming errors.
For the life of the product, for each run of the rubber, the pressure on suppliers and manufacturing partners to eliminate the most elemental recalls has jumped. The church has been saved money too, improving project costs by an unknown amount.
The project may be completed 2 to three years from a time, where the full-funnel cost will be shared by the congregation.

Addressing a business envelope correctly helps ensure that your letter gets to its intended recipient quickly. It’s important to follow standard practices for addressing correspondence, particularly if you are sending a letter to a large company with many departments or employees named Jane.
First, determine who you are writing to at the company. Generally, you will write the name of the addressee first—100 Main Street, John Smith, Sales Division, New York, NY, for example. This is best practice for addressing a business letter, and it shows respect to the recipient.
If the name of the addressee is unknown, it is important to write down their title or department instead. Many companies have departments within departments, so you might need to write down John Smith’s division as Sales Division, Vice President of Sales Division, or HR.
For international correspondence, the exact address of the recipient may be more important. You will also wish to know the postcode or zip code where the letter should be delivered. This information allows the postman to attempt delivery even if the addressee is out of the office at the time.

Hair loss is no longer an inevitable march to baldness. Medical advances in recent decades mean male hair loss can be treated, and it need not break the bank.
The cause of male pattern baldness is well established. It’s widely believed to be attached to genetic factors, and is passed down through your family tree. It’s also said to have a large bearing on whether or not one’s environment triggers the symptoms of the condition to kick in. It could be as easily a result of an extreme medical condition where the body produces too much or not enough hormones. Whatever the demise of the follicles, it is commonly attributed to male pattern baldness.
For centuries people looked for ways to halt this process which no doubt refers to one of the oldest subjects in human history; a reflection on the gender roles within human culture. For most of human history, a man’s appearance has been based on what is considered socially pleasing and attractive with little cause for concern around the concept of maintaining appearance. A memorial service is planned for Fort Bragg City Councilman Jere Melo at 2 p.m. Sept. 10 at the Timberwolf Stadium on Chestnut Street in Fort Bragg.
He died Aug. 24 from complications of a strained aorta, which doctors said had been eating away at his body for many years, essentially lining the artery with calcium.
At one point, Melo suffered another aortic attack and faced having one of his ankles amputated. Doctors were able to successfully clean the strain out and operate on him once again. Despite two additional surgeries to remove the calcium buildup again, Melo never recovered and had to undergo constant dialysis treatments.
At his death at age 66, Melo was rated one of the top city officials in Siskiyou County in overall effectiveness.

The United Kingdom could still remain a member of the European Union, but only if all other member states agree, said the leader of the second-largest political group in the European Parliament.
“Our door remains open, if the UK can propose something credible, such as staying in two years or having free movement for students while denouncing the rules of the single market, such as free movement of workers. In any case, they have to decide,” Guy Verhofstadt, the European Parliament’s Brexit spokesperson said. "If a country is out, it cannot have free movement agreements if we need to enforce [the right] for EU citizens. This is a fundamental European demand and would leave people like you or us outside the country," he stated.
Verhofstadt also said May’s offer of free movement for EU citizens in the UK was unacceptable and believes an all-inclusive deal on the free movement of people should not have to be accepted by only the UK.

Researchers are zooming in on a handheld camera that can reveal the unseen, inner structures of everything from concrete bridges to body parts.
Remember those X-ray glasses advertised in the back of comic books decades ago? Sure, they looked like fun, but they probably wouldn't meet current safety standards. Still, they fit well with a burgeoning interest in “interior” cameras that create images of structures inside a substrate. This field, called hyperspectral imaging, is making the leap from the laser cages of physics labs to the world at a distance—without those classic sunglasses.
The technique uses reflection and refraction to reveal inner features invisible to the human eye. "Amid all the noise, we are getting on with the job," Prime Minister Theresa May wrote in the Sunday Telegraph.
London: Prime Minister Theresa May said on Sunday she would not be derailed from leaving the EU without a deal in March to avert paralysis at a time when Britain must be much more focused on securing its future outside the bloc.
EU leaders have yet to agree any divorce terms despite a strongly worded ultimatum last week from Brussels: five meetings in the next 10 days to agree a deal and no further postponement of Britain`s planned exit on March 29.
"Amid all the noise, we are getting on with the job," May wrote in the Sunday Telegraph. "I am confident that with good faith and determination on all our parts we can make a success of Brexit."
Last week`s agreement to postpone Brexit until Jan. 31 if there was no divorce deal by Wednesday was a complete capitulation, more akin to handing in a blank piece of A4 and saying: "sort it out".

A Houston-area mother and son are suing activist Quanell X, alleging he passed himself off as a lawyer and took money for legal services he never delivered.
The seeds of the dispute started last year, when Mahkingie Jones attended a free pot bust case-review clinic run by the activist at a Dallas hotel meeting space.
She and several other Houston-area residents with weed possession charges took turns meeting with Casey Lauck, a Dallas lawyer whom Quanell identified in a tweet May 4 as his "longtime hired private investigator and criminal defense attorney," according to a federal suit filed last month. TOBYHANNA TOWNSHIP -- PennDOT is making an effort to improve safety conditions on two major highways in our area.
On Monday, crews began installing guide rails along Interstate 380, from just east of the I-80 interchange back to the Leigh Tyler Bridge. This will happen during the overnight hours and should be finished Wednesday morning.
"If one vehicle were to loose control on the road surface, the guide rail will help the vehicle maintain a little better control," highway safety manager Gary Slack said. "It is good preventative measure."
Guide rails were also installed last month on Interstate 81 in this area from I-380 all the way up to John F. Kennedy Memorial Highway, all as part initiative to reduce the number of deaths per year along the stretch from just short of 40 to 15 or less over the next 55 years.

Christian formation is the lifelong process of growing in our relationship with God, self, others, and all creation. Every experience in our lives can provide us with the opportunity to express our faith; the challenge we face is recognizing these opportunities. This course is designed to give you the tools you need to engage in this sacred dialogue. We will focus on the theology of the dialogue, the different forms the dialogue can take (e.g., journaling, volunteering, discussions, videos) and the methods required to celebrate the multiple opportunities we have to converse with God. You will grow to understand the different forms that learning and teachings can take, as well as the different methods needed to engage with these forms. Toward the end of the course, you will also discover the different ways faith can be expressed within our social and digital world, as well as ways that have helped you and others listen to and build on each other. You will demonstrate your awareness of the different ways that you express your Christianity by engaging in a peer-learning activity. Learning how to answer tough interview questions can help you get the job you want.
Interview questions that ask you what you will contribute to the company are designed to help employers weed out the best applicants. Your answer to this question should clearly provide examples of previous work experience that show how ambitious and result-oriented you are. You should also highlight specific soft skills such as communication, collaboration and problem-solving abilities that set you apart as a valuable employee. To do this effectively, prepare answers for each of the following question categories.
1. Describe a problem you faced in your job and what you did to fix it.
• Identify the most problematic issue from a previous position or one you encountered in college.
• Highlight why the issue was so problematic.
• Describe how you addressed the issue over time and what you accomplished.
2. Give me an example of a time where you achieved something great.
• Give a specific example, such as an increase in sales numbers, an improvement in customer feedback, or success in getting a new hire onboard. Provide data demonstrating how important your effort was.
3. How do you take

Abu Dhabi Police will enforce lower speed limits during hazardous weather conditions from this Sunday.
The force said reduced speed limits will be posted on electronic signboards on roads and sent out by SMS, the Arabic-language Khaleej Times said on Sunday. Images of the messages were posted on social media.
Speed limit signs currently show 110km/h for normal conditions, but will reduce to 65km/h for different hazard levels.
They include light rain, fog, flood, strong wind, rain with hail, rain with high wind, heavy rain, torrential rain with high wind, rain storm, hail storm, flood around a wadi, tornado, whirlwind, dust storm and sandstorm.
On Sunday, authorised Abu Dhabi police officers began ticketing impatient drivers for breaking the reduced speed limit, according to a tweet from the Gulf News English-language daily.
In May, road authorities in Dubai issued 257 motorists traffic tickets, because they had been caught driving at a speed of more than 65km/h.

Emigrated Cubans in the US city of Miami, Florida, are preparing today for a debate on August 26 about the new Constitution project of their native country.
That meeting, the first of three planned for the same purpose, will be held at one of the most important Catholic churches in the city, the St Stephen Cathedral.
Sponsored by the Union of Cuba Immigrants, the event should attract more than 600 Cubans born on the Island, as well as thousands of Cubans living in that municipality 600 km from the Cuban sea.
“We must see with optimism, despite reduced expectations of our government. This new Constitution is a very big deal and it is necessary to have strategic and intelligent discussion on every piece of information and purported ‘document’ that later evolves,” Martin Palma, an opponent of the Cuban government from the city, told Diario Las Americas newspaper.
Sunday’s meeting will also be attended by Cuban human rights activist Jorge Pinon, who will present his report about what occurred during and after the consultations held in Cuba as part of the new drafting process.

A car called the Excel is to go on sale in the United States for the first time Thursday morning. It is an unremarkable looking vehicle, resembling many of the small, efficient Japanese cars that have wrested a large share of the American market from their U.S. manufacturer competitors.
But the Excel, a four-seater with a mid-mounted engine, relies on some innovative technology, including a "hybrid power train." BOSTON (AP) — An Amtrak employee suffered an apparent heart attack and later died after a train struck a piece of construction equipment near where he was working early Thursday morning, officials said.
The Albany, N.Y.-bound Capital Corridor was en route from Portland, Ore., when it hit the construction equipment at just after midnight, Amtrak said in a statement. The train came to a halt, but the crew members continued onto the crawler. They continued to Oakland, Calif., 40 miles away, where it's scheduled to stop and take on another crew. four passenger cars were derailed and off the rails.
Amtrak said the train later continued on its route at a reduced speed, arriving 48 minutes behind schedule at Emeryville, Calif., just west of Oakland. No passengers were injured.
Amtrak said the crew members and one person working in trackside construction were unharmed. The crew members have been permanently relieved of duty in light of the incident and company rules, Amtrak officials said in a news conference Thursday afternoon.

The pair contested that they wouldn't receive a fair and unbiased verdict in the case that has gripped public attention all year as rumors swirled regarding motives and politics. In court, the attorneys of the men said they had lost faith in the legal process in Israel and so the Legal Council for Affairs of Foreign Deportees requested the citizen's trial to be held outside the country.
"I applied for a change of venue," defense attorney Geula Even-Porat said. "This is a case that raises sensational and critical issues of state and international politics." She argued that isn't necessary, however, sufficed the legal process of the Supreme Court of Justice to decide this issue.
The Justice Ministry issued a statement Thursday on the saga, calling into question, directly, the possible political agenda in presenting the French pair's case to the Supreme Court.

SALT LAKE CITY — Recent reports show that Utah's charter schools are improving, but are they doing enough to keep up with charter schools in other states?
Utah's overall score from the study by Expanded Standards Project places Utah number five in the nation when ranking charter schools.
While Utah may have done well in the report, it has a ways to go before catching most other states with the goals it set out.
St. George — and Cedar City — Wins Awards From State for First 4 Years
Known as the "Each Pupil Campus" statewide initiative, the goals specified by Utah lawmakers are challenges two to three times bigger than those in most states, Sandra Long of Expanded Standards Project said.
Long is a project director. She has been compiling many of the Zions Bank Charter School Finance Study reports since the project began.
She said the statewide goals established by the state are not where most other states have their charter schools.
The biggest difference is money. Most other states use fewer tests than Utah does.

Your credit card company doesn't have your best interests at heart.
Credit cards have caused financial pain for millions of consumers. It's easy to run up a balance, but as too many people find out the hard way, trying to catch up can be as tough as climbing a mountain. It's all too common to see the balance in a credit card statement suddenly skyrocket even as the consumer diligently sticks to a fairly consistent repayment schedule. The reason is that credit card issuers abuse their customers with sky-high annual percentage rates on ungodly, impenetrable "double-cycle" fees (which harvests your prepayments and then levies interest on the prepayments you thought you had already paid); interest charges for already-credited balances; and cunning delays that inflate rates even as repayments shrink balances as fast as possible. In some cases, the abuses are pathologic: For millions of Americans, more of the monthly statement balances charged them in a given month were actually interest charges rather than outstanding purchases. Some independent experts say DNA testing is inadequate for analyzing botanical products.
ALBANY, N.Y. — DNA barcoding has exposed some infamous cases of food fraud, like cheap catfish passed as lobster and spinach faked as Parmesan cheese. Now a coalition of scientists and biotechnology experts are trying to convince government regulators that DNA testing should be more regularly performed on herbal products to ensure their contents match their labels.
"It was always the case that consumers would bring a bottle of something... and they'd say, well, it said on the bottle ‘wild harvested.' And so it was always the case that people felt a little misled," said Jeff Miller, an associate professor of botanical medicine and DNA extraction and quantification at the School for Biological Sciences at the University of Natural Medicine (formerly known as Bastyr University) in Seattle.
EXPALNED: Whoops! Most plants of mustard variety called Apexanger 401 are not drought, heat tolerant after all.

The US economy “remains strong”, the Federal Reserve chairman, Jerome Powell, told Congress on Tuesday as he signaled the central bank is on course to carry on gradually increasing interest rates in the coming months.
In his prepared opening statement, Powell said GDP growth has rebounded in the past few months after stagnating late last year. Both the job market and inflation have also strengthened, the Fed chair added.
The Fed, however, has shifted its language away from the term “patient” as officials continue to assess how long they will keep raising rates — and when. Most investors now believe rates have reached a top around 2.75%, although the Fed’s median forecast still sees rates increasing to 3% by the end of the year.

A message in a bottle that washed up more than 108 years after it was thrown into the sea may be the world's oldest, a marine association has said.
The bottle was released in the North Sea between the Netherlands and Sweden by Henry Spille in about 1864.
He had written on the message "Will this get to you Henry write again when possible send to Amsterdam Holland", it said.
Last August, it was discovered on North Happisburgh beach in Norfolk, England - more than 5,259 km from where it was launched.

2 Can You Make Money Being a Web-hosting Reseller?
Web hosting companies earn money by selling server space to individuals and businesses. While some larger companies own their server farms, smaller providers rent space from major firms that offer this server space at a profit. Resellers rent interior server space from wholesale hosts for individuals and businesses. It’s a quick and easy business with low overhead costs. If you want to look for hosting reseller opportunities as a business idea, this guide will show you how you can build mine.
Create a compelling website. It doesn’t have to cost a lot of money. Consider some inexpensive options such as WordPress to eliminate the need to hire someone. You will need to offer customers fast, free hosting in exchange for full-price services. The rate of babies who die during their first year of birth has improved nationally in the last decade, but in recent years, improvement in this key public health metric has plateaued.
New data released by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention shows the national Neonatal Fatality Rate, or death within the first 28 days of birth, has slowly improved to 4.2 babies per 1,000 live births during 2013. It’s the lowest rate observed since 2011 data was made available, showing the effects of many state and local health agencies and community hospitals working together in a network that includes the Federation of Neonatal Information Services (feds) and the Neonatology Quality Improvement Collaborative (Neo QIC) on behalf of the healthcare industry. The Neo QIC/feds collaborative includes more than 400 children’s hospitals, affiliated state agencies, medical centers, medical societies, and individual physicians and others working to improve neonatal health care. The Public Service Commission on Wednesday approved a pilot program intended to create up to 350 megawatts of long-term renewable power within the next three years, a move that state officials and environmentalists say could help expedite the state’s renewable-energy goal. It might even benefit ratepayers.
Both ends of state government, however, saw the initial response to Gov. Josh Douglas’ Regional Renewable Energy Initiative as lukewarm: The governor’s office, environmentalists and energy advocates expected more critical reaction from public power companies.
The new PSC program includes elements favored by both sides — stringent mutually-reliant market rules intended to ensure energy supply, bulk tax credits, subsidized power purchase agreements and renewable-energy credits awarded retroactively to participating utilities. It was designed after many months of negotiation among a range of power interests, consumer groups and renewables advocates. It also was born December 6, the day the state changed its renewable-energy requirement from a 5% minimum renewable demand by 2011 up to 15%

Earth requires fuel to drive plate tectonics, volcanoes and its magnetic field. Like a hybrid car, Earth taps two sources of energy to run its engine: primordial energy from assembling the planet and nuclear energy from the heat generation of the planet. "The potential to use 'green fuels' to power plate tectonics, volcanoes and Earth's magnetic field has long interested and frustrated Earth scientists," says Associate Professor Sarah Depress, Yale University, whose findings appear in the journal Nature Geoscience. "To determine whether nuclear energy is a viable source of future Earth energy, we need to learn how energy production and consumption evolve together in a time machine environment. That is a tall order for computer models that can easily deal with one or the other, but not both, for very long. This REU program is designed to bridge that gap."

(CNN) — Elephants are giant, cancer-battling super creatures that destroy damaged cells long before they become cancerous, scientists say.
In a study released this week, scientists said elephant cells known as “mesenchymal stem cells” detected a problem long before microscopic cancer-causing tumors could form and destroyed the cells before cancer formed. This microscopic combat wasn’t fur-deep — the cells fired out chemicals to slay the intruding mutating cells, the paper said.
Elephant life can translate into preventive treatment targets for people. In the next decade scientists could find ways to slow or even stop cancer from forming, said lead study author Ian Zagon, a neuroscientist at the State University of New York, Binghamton.
Since elephants sometimes live more than five decades and have an allopathic life cycle with few age related health issues, Zagon said, the cells should figure out ways to fix damaged and slow cells.

BOSTON – A disgraced former state chemist may have tainted more prosecutions than officials had first estimated, an independent reviewer of narcotics cases said Tuesday.
More than 400 convictions of illegal drug traffickers may have to be vacated if blood-testing results are invalidated, covering the period when laboratory analyst Annie Dookhan was mistakenly given responsibility to independently vouch for blood-testing of seized drugs, the state capital reported Monday.
It would mark the second time in two years Massachusetts courts had vacated hundreds of convictions because an errant state chemist caused junk science prosecutions. Defense lawyers have only succeeded in overturning about 10 percent of cases where faulty chemistry tainted evidence, the paper reported.
Drug lab chemist Annie Dookhan testified in Massachusetts state courts about 46,000 times over nine years, as defendants were sentenced and sent to prison for several different drugs, including heroin and ecstasy.

New analysis shows 22 of Australia’s largest companies are actively working to undermine the Paris agreement targets, betting shareholders’ money on strategies that assume global climate change action fails.
Investor action group Market Forces took voluntary financial disclosures presented by Santos, Woodside Energy, EnergyAustralia, and AGL Energy to uncover potentially more than A$11bn ($8bn) in proposed spending over the next 15 years or until corporate targets are realised.
Many companies are using new projects enhanced oil recovery, the gas industry “crude oil for trains to Poland” strategy, coal export expansion and are seeking new rounds of permitting to drift past government commitments.
Market Forces then analysed public filings and filsecrets to calculate how at least eight of the companies in the top 40 are using or seeking public funds for such projects. They include tapping the cash savings of councils, schools and other state-owned entities such as not-for-profit trust funds or land trusts.

This polygon shapefile contains ice observations in the Arctic region for July 3, 1980. This layer is part of the Arctic Climate System (ACSYS) Historical Ice Chart Archive. The earliest chart in the data set comes from 1553, when Sir Hugh Willoughby and Richard Chancellor, commanders of two expeditions sent out by the Company of Merchant Adventurers, recorded their observations of the winter ice off the coast of Russia in Arctic Cartographic Journal. The chart collection was acquired as a comprehensive geophysical data set to use in conjunction with results of marine, glaciological, meteorological, and other geophysical data sets (e.g., gravity, magnetic) for potential correlations or evolutionary studies of the environment. There are over 700 maps archived in this accession. Criteria for selecting the charts included: (a) predominantly sea-ice cover, the majority of the year, (b) relatively large lines of constant potential temperature and salinity, (c) simple low and constant bathymetry allowing estimation of transports and mass balance, (e) little disturbing influence

Karnow died of pneumonia at a hospital in Washington, D.C. Karnow’s daughter Frances Drew said her mother spoke to her father on Friday, as he had been suffering for a number of days. Karnow covered more than 25 years of the global news cycle beginning with Pakistan in 1959, He started the United Press in 1961, then moved to Time in 1965, becoming bureau chief in Saigon a decade later.
Karnow broke his connection with Time in 1975 to write Vietnam: A History, a 666 page, single-volume book in the time that nearly two-dozen other academics and journalists wrote thousands of page

Decision trees help people identify the pros and cons of business choices.
A decision tree is a visual tool used to help business professionals weigh the pros, cons and various approaches to major tasks or decisions. A decision tree can help professionals in predictive analysis by allowing the rendering of an outlook based on the most likely and hypothetical outcomes. This tool is a simple but effective way to display a range of possibilities given a set of initial conditions. Business leaders and analysts can compile decision-tree information into templates on platforms such as excel. These templates can be utilized with other tools such as investment calculators and pro forma analyses.
A Post Operative Decision Tree can show the variety of methods to lower blood glucose levels and the possible outcomes.
Decision trees are a nonlinear and interactive calculative tool. Mainly utilized in rendering judgment involving a number of intelligible criteria, they are commonly used in a judicial capacity. The Waste Land as an iPad app demonstrates how we might re-imagine the book, but it also illustrates how editorial choices can limit value.
The Guardian recently documented a June trek of 25 people through T. S. Eliot’s famous poem, The Waste Land, as part of an OU investigative journalism course conceived and run by Andrew Mackie. In The Waste Land as an iPad App, MAC explores the poem and gives each section a visual spin, taking more liberty with it than any other website, despite less than 1% of the poem’s value being altered as audio. This sort of tinkering with ebooks (with added audio?) is exciting, but The Waste Land app turned out unsatisfying because MacMaster chose to stop editing T. S. Eliot’s work after his death. It’s a topic I’ve covered before: using rare editions to diacritize biblical commentaries and healing the forgotten texts of T. S. Eliot’s life and work. So what we really want is every text available as a novel interpretation that we might make use of.

Pat Maloney was a gifted experimental musician in the 1970s, until he suddenly stopped playing entirely.
This story starts with an ending.
Pat Maloney passed away in the late summer of 2015. It was sad news of course, both for me and many others. It was also an unexpected and dramatic ending to a 4-year project in which I’d been given exclusive access to Maloney’s recorded archive after an online auction. It was also the sudden end of Pat Maloney’s musical career of more than two decades, during which time he used recorded sounds in innovative ways on eleven LPs. UN Secretary General Ban Ki-moon has been re-elected to serve a second five-year term, in a vote at the UN General Assembly.
Ban, current UN chief, received 158 votes out of a possible 193, while his chief rival, Prince Zeid Ra'ad Zeid Al-Hussein, the permanent representative of Jordan to the UN, picked up 11 votes.
Ban will take up his second term on 1 January, after his second term ends on 31 December, which local NGOs say stems from a quirk in the UN's rules.
The next scheduled election for UN chief is in 2016.
Ban, who came to office in 2007, has had a rocky term in office, overseeing the aftermath of the financial crises and food and climate crises in Haiti and Pakistan and Libya.
He was also tarnished recently when an audit highlighted how he had been chauffeured around town by internal UN security staff

Analysis: OpenMFG helps fill the void of open-source ERP applications for small and midsized businesses.
For the largest enterprises, access to the source code of their enterprise resource planning applications is a given -- just another part of the franchise versions of SAP AGs R/3 with SAP Development Kits. For the lowest end of the ERP market, however, the ability to get into the code has been much rarer. Without source access, most small businesses without deep pockets have to stick with licensing increasingly mush-brained retail packaged applications. All they are missing is OpenMFG, the first open-source ERP application specifically targeted at the mid-market business with annual revenues that rarely go above $10 million.

The Family and Medical Leave Act of 1993 was enacted to protect employees who need to take absences from work to care for themselves or their family members due to medical problems. This law was amended in 2008 with the federal Health Act Amendments which dramatically increased the number of employees eligible to receive Family Leave Act benefits. Many states have also enacted family Leave acts. Among them are Colorado, Delaware, the District of Columbia, Maine, Maryland, Massachusetts, Nevada, Oregon, Vermont, Washington and California.
Who are the employees under FMLA?
Individuals are probably under Federal Family Leave Act as follows:
(1) You are probably you have a full-time or part-time employer of at least 50 employees
(2) To continue with your work for more than 12 months in a year, work with daily or partial weekly work
(3) Work at least 15 hours in a given workweek.

“We turned the former front office area into a cool and cozy taproom,” Hovley says.
Corrugated metal panels were added to the walls, set off by plenty of wood trim, giving the diminutive space an earth-tone, rustic feel. Lights dangle like Christmas ornaments from one long corner of the taproom ceiling, casting a soft glow anywhere guests are sitting. In a contemporary concession to growlers, some bottlenecks are being torn down, just like breweries in olden times. What is now the pouring station — the taproom’s main floor level — is a former generator hall. For all its renovations and improvements, the taproom is still a part of River Mill. Work still goes on across the hallway, behind curtained walls. As in a house, the taproom is a mixture of living room, dining room and kitchen — “a 2018 version of what people lived with by necessity back in the day,” Hovley says.
Hovley says the taproom is very popular — a loafing room or a party barn depending upon the time of day.

“With half billion dollars in offerings, growing revenue averaging 40% annually for 11 years, and the most relevant security portfolio after Symantec, McAfee and CheckPoint, Avast is now a mature, disciplined global firm,” said Vince Steckler, CEO, Avast Software. How do I know when I should exit a trade?
Are there some rules on this that I can follow?
Many traders approach their strategy with one thing in mind: establishing the qualifications for entry. The ‘edge’ if you will in their rules based on price and other indicators can create an edge at entry time, but what about in time to exit?
When choosing an exit will color with benign, it is important of course, that they create a risk profile that is comfortable for them in the first place (after they are examining ways in which they are implementing what they perceive to be a possible edge from elementary pattern studies). If it is their turn or an entry is appropriate, they may look for confirmation of that, then of course, looking to have their stops out. They rely upon a time, whether a time element, an indicator, or a technical pattern formation from some complex indicator database. It might be news, a partial profit target zone. It could even be a timing of the non-eventful disruption to their current activity, such as, arriving home from a vacation. They pick their times and feel they are as accountable as they are responsible.

An environmental art project launched at a centre for adults with learning difficulties has attracted interest from the upper echelons of the Welsh Assembly.
The sculptor Richard Houghton and service users at Tyddyn Môn at Criccieth designed and produced a series of bronze casts for display at Ruthin Castle. The project aims to use the castle ruins to highlight sustainability, crop rotation, preserving heather, the history of the castle and the landscape.
Richard Houghton explained: “The art centre at Criccieth has been very supportive throughout this process, offering the users and staff training in wax production and casting with foundry partners Ashran Plastik.
Joanne Banks, head of the art centre, said: “This has been a very successful and friendly working relationship resulting in a number of positive outcomes; working out unique methodologies, selecting site themes with relevance to each of the individuals and working through the casting process together.”

ZURICH, April 10 (Reuters) - Sunrise Communications' top shareholder on Wednesday blocked plans to extend the company's right to issue fresh capital to 2021, compounding pressure on the firm to defend its market leading position and combat growing competition.

Thanks to ever more sophisticated technology, it is much easier to obtain data - and to analyze it - than was thought possible even a few years ago. As a result, there is an understandable feeling that decision-making in organizations can be done much better because of that. In reality, this is a misleading illusion.
My thesis is this: it is not hard to collect data; it is hard to acquire the right amount of data. But analyzing large sets of data, it is not nearly as hard as it is made out to be. The principal reasons are a purely human one, namely that social phenomena are complex and very often not mutually consistent: The real problem then is not data volume, but data quality and consistency. This human “problem” has been one central theme of my own research.
In computer science, we try to answer questions using complete, well-defined languages. Formulating complex questions to a computer sounds simple, but we have to study carefully about what kind of interpretations we allow before expect to discover new phenomena. In human sciences, our ideas should mature in a broader, more unpredictable environment. This twin concept is the

On the plane, the airline crew noticed that a loading tray had fallen through a ceiling and become wedged on the side. The incident occurred 40 minutes after the flight took off from the airport.

While cybersecurity should be a year-round concern for small business owners, income tax filing season can bring some particular risks, according to the IRS.
The agency says it has gotten an increase in reports of fraud tactics associated with the tax season, including "phishing" emails or texts from IRS impersonators.
The tax agency says it is also becoming increasingly alert to cyber-scams involving bogus charities for "victims of the disatrous" 2017 hurricane season.
For Joseph Haag, an IRS cybersecurity specialist, it is partly fin-tech integrated banking that raises those risks.
Banks and other financial institutions scan activity for fraud and may have specialized security features that reduce risks for taxpayers and other clients, says Haag.

Prince Edward Island's fertilizer has never been more abundant, without the help of synthetic food-grade nitrogen products.
But now that clean organic options like Guano Poop and natural matrices rich in nitrogen, such as legume forage, are readily available, growers don't have to rely on potassium nitrate fertilizer. This non-native brine product is preferred for its high efficacy, ease of use, good logistics with loading equipment and wagons, and steady production. Knowing this, the United States banned it in 2013 and the province hoped to follow suit in 2019.

James Vincent Napoli, 41, of Eltingville and Boca Raton died April 7, 2019, at home in bed of a heart attack.
Born in Brooklyn and raised on Staten Island, N.Y., he lived in Boca Raton and Staten Island. Mr. Napoli spent much of his life shuttling back and forth between Staten Island and various points in the southern United States. In early adulthood he worked as a forklift operator. In his later years he established himself as a chef with numerous restaurants on the run in the Virgin Islands, Florida, Georgia, South Carolina, and the West Coast saving every penny to fund his retirement in a Florida retirement community. Nevertheless, Mr. Napoli’s predominant love and life passion was cooking. This pursuit was the driving force behind his adult life’s other interests which included saltwater aquariums and tropical fish, distilled spirits, animals, holistic medicine, the arts, ‘80s glam metal music and classic rock ’n’ roll from years past. Federal budget shows big support for Boys & Girls Clubs in Memphis and across the country, which are helping more at-risk youth stay out of trouble and in school.
For more than 56 years, the Boys & Girls Clubs of America have been an invaluable support to at-risk youth helping them stay out of trouble and stay in school. And according to a 2011 iQuantify study, students in the United States who belong to a Boys & Girls Clubs and that attended at least three nights a week had an impressive 14 percent reduction in risky behaviors, including illegal activity, fighting, bullying and missing school.
And thanks to a federal budget approved by the U.S. Senate and currently being considered in the House, Boys & Girls Clubs in places like Memphis will continue to see that level of growth and positive impact.
The Senate recently approved $540 million to support the programs, an increase of $10 million over last year with $114 million committed exclusively to local Boys & Girls Clubs. The House Budget-Deficit Reduction Committee is expected to consider the measure

NEW YORK — For a second year in a row, the NFL will air a dramatic PSA during the Super Bowl addressing the issue of domestic violence.
This year’s video shows a succession of text messages between two friends — one of whom has been working up the nerve to endure his girlfriend’s violent behavior. Finally, as the cancelled flight number flashes atop a smartphone screen — and is echoed then clarified to cancelled flight, the message becomes clear. By staying silent, the young man is allowing the dangers lurking just below the surface to overwhelm him. It’s all right there in black-and-white.
In a 97-second YouTube clip below the message is amplified. “Men, this is a message for you from the NFL. It’s on us,” a male-scented voiceover intones. “If someone has been hurt… report it.”
Joe Lockhart, the NFL’s chief communications officer, confirmed to Yahoo Tech that the spot is a part of the NFL’s “It’s on Us campaign” in partnership with the White House.

Pep Guardiola believes his brilliant Brazilian midfielder Fernandinho can extend his Manchester City career by moving back to central defense on a permanent basis as he ages.
His versatility has also seen him look to play in deeper roles during the two full campaigns of guiding the champions both on and off the field, having joined City from Shakhtar Donetsk in September 2013.
“I agree. I didn’t know he is a spare defender,” Guardiola, who nevertheless has a defender worthy of the tag in John Stones, says on Fernandinho playing in back three.

From the outlook of a planet that resides next to a quiet, relatively predictable star, the circumstances that lead to dramatic stellar explosions elsewhere in the universe can sound somewhat improbable. Some such blasts, known as supernovae, are powerful enough to emit radiation capable of killing all their resident planets and stripping away an Earth-like planet's atmosphere, making life possible on the surface of that planet unlikely. Other supernovae, meanwhile, are routinely dim enough to ultimately miss posting any significant changes for an Earth-like environment as they slowly peter into oblivion.
But while the exact results of stars exploding are hard enough to predict based on mathematical models alone, determining exactly how likely such a change of an otherwise typical life location is quite a challenge in and of itself. How can we think we might be able to concieve of the destinations that lie beyond our current exploration potential in any great detail now when our modes of travel and cognition will so far into the future allow us to observe and interact with our futures in unimaginable ways?

(CNN) – The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention has issued guidelines for the first time on treating children with concussions, saying they will provide doctors with the “tools they need to ensure the right treatment is given.”
The agency said on Friday “concussion” cannot be used in children because “the brain does not fully develop until age 20 to 25.”
Previously, the brain injury was called a “mild traumatic brain injury (TBI)” in children younger than 19 because “when pediatric patients are younger (less developed) than 19-years-olds’ brains, more of the tissue can become permanently impaired than in an older more developed brain,” the CDC said.
The agency described persistent or delayed symptoms – including drowsiness or sleep problems – as a potential problem and said doctors should consider post-concussion syndrome “if all [cognitive] test results are normal but symptoms last more than six months.”

UCLA researchers and colleagues have designed a new device that creates electricity from falling snow. The first of its kind, this device is inexpensive, small, thin and flexible like a sheet of plastic.
The researchers said they calculated that a single sheet of the device could generate about two watts of power for every four centimeters of variable snow depth overlying the device. This equates to about 30 kilowatt-hours annually generated in a 1-kilometer-wide strip of variable snow depth of 40 centimeters, they said. This is enough to meet the energy needs of an internet of things (IoT) device every day for its entire three-year life cycle. The new device could also be deployed in unreliable grid regions, support the mass adoption of miniature electronics, cold environments and earthquake zones by those who rely on renewable energy but live in cold climates where reliable sources are scarce.

I’ve always had an interest in colour. Coming from Scotland, where the weather often turns everything grey, I used to love how the landscape would transform when the sun came out. I had a view of the Ochil hills from my bedroom window and I remember playing with mixing discarded wood to look like trees (I entered this competition when I was 4). More recently, it always made me smile that Scotland a country which only has around 10 hours of sunlight in each 24 hours, has a wife and cottage industry selling tweed products, as well as knitwear companies, as if a wee tartan huddle in your window would keep everybody warm! I still love the light in winter, don’t misunderstand me. My interest in colour however has often been towards a classical style of florals. This has had little to do with kitsch prints on the wall, but usually integrating colour and shape in a simple, elegant way. My space was always full of colour. At one point during an episode of the CW's mystery series Cult, one of the characters makes another the impassioned promise that "There will be an answer!" Given the show's intense love affair with metafiction, that bit of dialogue seemed decidedly off the mark. It was clearly the desperate proclamation of a character who'd been chasing a conspiracy-free episode. And yet, it could also be seen as a promise made in the hopes that, just this once, the mystery buried in this town (the titular Cult) would finally make some sense.
For a show that began in thrall to a brooding disingenuousness, the series soon developed into a fractured postmodern headache that offered no lucid solution for why such a hideously entertaining narrative was crammed into an indescribably stocky box. Rolling its sleeves a little closer to the state of what it outright claimed they were, the series fractured and shattered, examining how far one could go into commodifying reality in a postmodern world that refuses to offer anything without a hashtag already prominent

What are the lessons we can draw from the removal of leavened foods, and the bland crackers we eat for a full week?
Sometimes those challenging moments, when we feel that we have been flattened and/or that God has given us a specific challenge, threaten our foundations. How could leaven be so threatening to God? Why do those seven days we’re given to enrich our bakery have to be so bland?
Jesus Christ gives us exactly these opportunities every year to look back to Moses and what happened to ancient Israel. The episode with leaven is an important reminder for our sanctified, refined souls—that we need to be careful on whose property we live, what company we choose to keep, what we listen to and pray with. God wants US to choose him over any of the distractions we failed to fast from before. It’s not just food and drink. Nothing passive about God. Yet it is not ALL or NOTHING either. What's More Important: Your Product Or Proof-Of-Concept?
I have had the luxury of meeting over 500 startups at Red Rocket Ventures over the last three years. And, typically, once they get over the awkwardness that attendants are “interns” under the guise of an independent contractor, they usually talk about how important their traction, like a massive and populous Facebook app. This makes me cringe and bit my tongue when appropriate. Those sorts of beautiful, little pitches are too common today. It’s touching in its misguidance I suppose.
But, that’s not what you have to pitch. You have to pitch whatever will increase your scale-ability… and that means your business model. How you are ultimately monetized has to be locked-down to be able to attract meaningful recurring traction months (or even years) from now. Too often the ideas, the “cooler” piece, gets in-the-way of the real issue (their stickiness). It’s a trap you want to avoid.

The prolonged oil slump has led to losses at energy companies and oil-producing countries alike.
While it might have left countries like Venezuela close to economic collapse, it's also left gaping holes in the national budgets of the world's top oil-producing nations as well.
One of the biggest losers from the downturn is Russia, which the IMF estimates lost approximately $125 billion over the course of the downturn and saw its account drop from a 54% surplus to a 2014 deficit of 3%.
To make matters worse, it is extremely difficult — if not impossible — to grab money back from an oil producer under any kind of investment living situation. This includes nonpayment of dividends and suspension of formal reimbursement for acquisitions that never took place.
Last October, Russian officials took aim at French oil major Total after its investment SFD (an oil and gas field in southern Muchukta, northern Sakhalin), was abandoned. Total had put $3.1 billion into the asset, including future reserves that more likely would have a very long payback period

Legislators are considering the establishment of a strategic environmental assessment system to evaluate the consequences of governmental policies and planning on the environment and to ensure sustainable development in the country.
Such a system will be legalized by a proposed amendment to a 2006 law on investment climate which under discussion at the National Assembly.
Economists and experts on plannning and international cooperation fully support the idea.
Indeed, it is common sense that sound policies are critical for sustainability. Policymakers and planners often fail to recognize the environmental impacts of the projects they pursue.
Former environment minister, Nguyen Minh Hoang, an advocate of such assessment, says environmental planning is critical on any project which deals with physical infrastructure.
“It is also important with human resources management. But the recommended law leaves some issues unsettled. It does not clearly address how to develop plans and how to examine when they are being implemented and what they are supposed to achieve. It just introduces the responsibility of planning and implementation, but not their responsibilities and scope,” Hoang told VET.

President Anwar al-Sadat of Egypt has broken all relations with Syria, Libya, Algeria and South Yemen.
He has ordered their diplomats to leave Egypt within 24 hours and recalled his envoys in those countries, the Egyptian Foreign Ministry announced.
The four Arab modern socialist republics are among the most estranged of the Arab nations. They fought on the side of the former Soviet Union in Syria's war with Israel in 1973.
Egyptian officials gave no reason for the break but the action followed an excerpt of an article in a weekly magazine published Sunday that renewed allegations that Egypt and Syria were supplying Libya with instruments of torture and other war equipment in the five-year-long dispute over oil revenue between Libya and other rebel movements in southern Iraq.

LAHORE: The provincial capital, Lahore is among the most polluted cities in the world and urgent action needs to be taken to tackle this issue. Air pollution caused by traffic, industries, crop burning and burning rubbish piles can cause respiratory and cardiovascular diseases and may lead to premature deaths, warn local experts. Prof Sabia Saeed Quddusi, a consultant pediatrician said children under 5 and the elderly are among the most vulnerable to air pollution. In Lahore, she cited children exposed to indoor pollution and families with heating appliances like terra cotta stoves placed beside windows. "The biggest cause is particulate matter that causes cancer and heart disease,” she said.

In turn, FFA will help its members tap into surrounding communities and networks that can support them in specialized areas. Largely responsible for repressing the post-coup crackdown were a tri-party coalition made up of the military, the police and tax authorities.

Kumar, Amnesty researcher on the Americas.

Dengue is most commonly spread by the daytime Aedes aegypti mosquito which transmits the dengue virus which ultimately causes fever, rashes and severe illnesses including dengue shock syndrome, unless treated immediately. It is also the leading cause of virological disease worldwide.

NAIROBI (Reuters) - The global price of cashew nuts has jumped nearly 10 percent over the past week, after Tanzania’s government started buying the entire country’s stock at a premium after spending days without the crop for cooking.
Expanding population is pushing food prices up at a time the United Nations warns climate is changing the supply and demand in many key commodities, including coffee.
Tanzania spends about $150 million to $160 million (£115.73 – £120.38) a year on cashew farming subsidies and is seeking $115 million for the annual division it pays wholesale processors as compensation.
Last week the government begun selling its subsidy directly to Tanzanians at higher prices. Before the deals started, wholesale prices in this year were about half the retail prices in this season, they are now three quarters above. When retail prices will go have yet to be announced.

The Marine Corps’ footprint in Afghanistan is changing dramatically as a drawdown in forces continues throughout the summer.
The latest changes include a shift in central Helmand province in which one infantry battalion — 3rd Battalion, 6th Marines — has been moved to tactical reserve, freeing up eight companies and nearly 650 Marines, the Corps said on Friday.
Overall, the Marines are slated to lose about 4,200 personnel from when the Corps was operating at peak levels in Afghanistan in the spring. That number will continue to decline to below 6,200 by late summer.
That means Taliban fighters will have more time to rest and search for new sources of funding so they can continue fighting the Nato coalition long after most will have disappeared from Afghanistan by 2014.

Serious allegations have been made about the deaths of civilians at the hands of Turkish security forces in the overwhelmingly Kurdish town of Cizre in south-eastern Turkey earlier this year.
Local officials say the security forces killed between 393 and 406 civilians during a 75-day curfew, imposed on the town from December 2015 to January this year, reports the BBC.
One hundred houses were also destroyed in Cizre, the town officials added.
Kurdish militants said Turkish troops and gendarmes had killed more than four children during a night-time operation there in March.
Government officials have reported similar allegations in a number of villages in eastern Turkey where special security operations featured operations against Kurdistan Workers Party (PKK) militants.

Prepare for major changes in personal data sharing. The new General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR), a comprehensive plan to protect the security and privacy of personal data in the European Union, goes into effect on May 25. As the EU’s data privacy watchdog – the Office of the Data Protection – shares data-gathering best practices globally, companies with businesses located in or affiliated with the EU must take steps now to become GDPR-compliant. Should you obey the GDPR? You certainly wish! This is a mandate, and the fines for noncompliance can reach up to approximately $20 million or 4 percent of your global annual turnover – whichever is greater – per offense. Nature broke that pact Oct. 25, when a violent downpour unleashed unprecedented fury on the town of Vernazza and the surrounding hills along Italy’s northwestern coast, provoking dozens of landslides and bringing the town — and its narrow streets and buildings, all carved out of rock — altogether to a halt.
What is extraordinary about this catastrophe is how fluid the landscape of this town is and how changing its landscape is a constant. Such topography generated historic fecundity, as the rock was cracked open to plant vines. It was dubbed a monumental invention of man, quite a turn of phrase also used by Benjamin Franklin describing electricity — just as fate owed it to improve man, nature obliged it to dampen him. Nature should do this as a robust — if never predictable or verifiable — witness to history by granting no pact in its ceaseless evolution.

BEIJING — Mao Zedong famously dismissed the atomic bomb as a “paper tiger,” able to kill and terrify, but not decisive in war. Even so, China built a nuclear arsenal meant to respond forcefully to any instance of Chinese aggression.
But in 1971, President Richard M. Nixon traveled to Beijing, dislocating China in ways that reverberate today. China seemed at first like a curiosity for the United States: a party-in-power in theory but in truth ineffectual at execution, ruled by an inchoate proto-bureaucracy and hamstrung by a political structure described as “an army of persons ruthless and unscrupulous in seeking power and privilege,” as Secretary of Defense Robert S. McNamara had written to the White House chief-of-staff, H.R. Haldeman.

MANILA, December 24, 2004 (STAR) By Donnabelle Gatdula - The country’s three major oil companies along with several small oil players are cutting pump prices by another five centavos on New Year’s Day.
Because of the holiday January 1 is also “D-day” as it marks the close of the tangible down payment scheme and the inauguration of the energy rationing program.
Both of them are a part of government’s comprehensive program to lower-price petroleum or increase competition.
Now, Filipinos pay for gasoline at a maximum of P8.93 per liter and diesel at P6.96 by way of the scheme that offers the biggest discount of P3 to consumers. It opened on September 15 this year with rates of P9.12 for gasoline and P7.93 for diesel.
